===Atlases=== * ''Atlas of the World Deluxe'' * ''Atlas of the World'' * ''New Concise World Atlas'' * ''Essential World Atlas'' * ''Pocket World Atlas''
===Music=== * ''[[Carols for Choirs]]'' * ''[[Oxford Book of Carols]]'' * ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians]]'' * ''[[The Oxford Companion to Music]]'' * ''[[Oxford Book of English Madrigals]]'' * ''[[Oxford Book of Tudor Anthems]]'' * ''[[The Oxford History of Western Music]]''
==Scholarly journals== OUP as '''Oxford Journals''' has also been a major publisher of [[academic journals]], both in the sciences and the humanities; {{as of|2016|lc=y}} it publishes over 200 journals on behalf of learned societies around the world.<ref name="Journals">{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordjournals.org/en/ |title=Oxford Journals |publisher=OUP |accessdate=April 19, 2016}}</ref> It has been noted as one of the first university presses to publish an [[open access journal]] (''[[Nucleic Acids Research]]''), and probably the first to introduce [[Hybrid open access journal]]s, offering "optional open access" to authors to allow all readers online access to their paper without charge.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordjournals.org/our_journals/exbotj/open_access.html |title=Optional Open Access Experiment |publisher=Oxford Journals |work=[[Journal of Experimental Botany]] |accessdate=April 19, 2016}}</ref> The "Oxford Open" model applies to the majority of their journals.<ref name="Oxford Open">{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordjournals.org/en/oxford-open/index.html |title=Oxford Open |publisher=Oxford Journals |accessdate=April 19, 2016}}</ref> The OUP is a member of the [[Open Access Scholarly Publishers Association]].
==Clarendon Scholarships== Since 2001, Oxford University Press has financially supported the [[Clarendon bursary]], a [[University of Oxford]] graduate scholarship scheme.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the Clarendon Fund|url=https://www.ox.ac.uk/clarendon/about/history-of-the-clarendon-fund?wssl=1|website=www.ox.ac.uk|publisher=University of Oxford|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[:Category:Oxford University Press academic journals]] * [[List of Oxford University Press journals]] * ''[[Hachette (publishing)|Hachette]]'' * ''[[Hart's Rules]] for Compositors and Readers at the University Press, Oxford'' * [[List of largest UK book publishers]] * [[Cambridge University Press v. Patton]], a copyright infringement suit in which OUP is a plaintiff * [[Blackstone Press]] * [[Harvard University Press]] * [[Edinburgh University Press]] * [[Express Publishing]] * [[Blavatnik School of Government]] (opened in 2015), opposite the OUP on Walton Street
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |first=Nicolas |last=Barker |title=The Oxford University Press and the Spread of Learning |place=Oxford |date=1978 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Carter |first1=Harry Graham |authorlink1=Harry Carter (typographer) |title=A History of the Oxford University Press |place=Oxford |publisher=Clarendon Press |date=1975 |oclc=955872307 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |author=[[Rimi B. Chatterjee]] |title=Empires of the Mind: A History of the Oxford University Press in India During the Raj |place=New Delhi |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=2006 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |first=Duncan |last=Hinnells |title=An Extraordinary Performance: Hubert Foss and the Early Years of Music Publishing at the Oxford University Press |place=Oxford: OUP |isbn=978-0-19-323200-6 |date=1998 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |publisher=Oxford University Press Music Department |title=Oxford Music: The First Fifty Years '23−'73 |place=London: OUP |date=1973}} * {{cite book |first=Peter |last=Sutcliffe |title=The Oxford University Press: An Informal History |place=Oxford: Clarendon Press |isbn=0-19-951084-9 |date=1978}} * {{cite book |first=Peter |last=Sutcliffe |title=An Informal History of the OUP |place=Oxford: OUP |date=1972 |ref=harv}}

''The History of Oxford University Press: Volume II: 1780 to 1896.'' Oxford: OUP. {{ISBN|9780199543151}}. * [[William Roger Louis|Louis, William Roger]], ed. (2014). ''The History of Oxford University Press: Volume III: 1896 to 1970.'' Oxford: OUP. {{ISBN|9780199568406}}. Also online DOI:10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199568406.001.0001. * [[Keith Robbins|Robbins, Keith]], ed. (2017). ''The History of Oxford University Press: Volume IV: 1970 to 2004.'' Oxford: OUP. {{ISBN|9780199574797}}.

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Yuzhi Wuti Qingwen Jian Tian.svg|thumb|280px|The first page of the astronomy section of the ''Yuzhi Wuti Qing Wenjian''. The work contains four terms on each of its pages, arranged in the order of Manchu, Tibetan, Mongolian, Chagatai, and Chinese languages. For the Tibetan, it includes both transliteration and a transcription into the [[Manchu alphabet]]. For the Chagatai, it includes a line of transcription into the Manchu alphabet.
(Work completed during the [[Qianlong Emperor|Qianlong era]] of the [[Qing dynasty]].)
]] The '''''Pentaglot Dictionary'''''{{cite book|title=Bibliographies of Mongolian, Manchu-Tungus, and Tibetan Dictionaries|volume=Volume 20 of Orientalistik Bibliographien und Dokumentationen|ISSN=1436-0195|issue=|first=|last=|editor1-first=Larry V.|editor1-last=Clark|editor2-first=John Richard|editor2-last=Krueger|editor3-first=Hartmut|editor3-last=Walravens|editor4-first=Manfred|display-editors = 3 |editor4-last=Taube|others=Compiled by Larry V. Clark, John Richard Krueger, Hartmut Walravens, Manfred Taube|editor-first=|editor-last=|edition=annotated|year=2006|publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CaoXrIqxsJ4C&pg=PA39#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=39|isbn=3447052406|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}Mimaki, Katsumi. A Tibetan Index to the Pentaglot Dictionary from the Qing Dynasty. JIATS 1988. (Chinese: 御製五體清文鑑, ''Yuzhi Wuti Qing Wenjian''; the term 清文, ''Qingwen'', "Qing language", was another name for the Manchu language in Chinese), also known as the '''''Manchu Polyglot Dictionary''''',Publication (Field Museum of Natural History : 1909), Publication: Anthropological Series, Field Museum of Natural History{{cite book|title=Publication: Anthropological series, Volume 15, Issue 3|first=Berthold|last=Laufer|others=Contributor Field Museum of Natural History|editor-first=|editor-last=|volume=Volume 15|issue=Issue 3 of Fieldiana: Anthropology|edition=|year=1919|publisher=The Museum|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uZ8LAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA578#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=578|isbn=|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}Publication (Field Museum of Natural History : 1909), Publication: Anthropological Series, Field Museum of Natural History{{cite book|title=Publication: Anthropological series, Volume 15|issue=|first=Berthold|last=Laufer|others=Contributor Field Museum of Natural History|editor-first=|editor-last=|volume=|edition=|year=1917|publisher=The Museum|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Is4AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA578#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=578|isbn=|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} was a dictionary of major imperial languages compiled in the late [[Qianlong Emperor|Qianlong era]] of the [[Qing dynasty]] (also said to be compiled in 1794). The work contains [[Manchu language|Manchu]] lexemes and their translations into various administrative languages such as [[Classical Tibetan|Tibetan]], [[Classical Mongolian language|Mongolian]], post-classical or vernacular [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]] (Eastern [[Turki]], now known as [[Uyghur language|Modern Uyghur]] since 1921) and [[Chinese language|Chinese]]. ==Title== The literal meaning of the Chinese title 《御製五體清文鑑》 ''Yù zhì wǔ tǐ Qīng wén jiàn'' is "Imperially-Published Five-Script Textual Mirror of Qing", which corresponds to {{lang-mnc|m={{ManchuSibeUnicode|ᡥᠠᠨ ᡳ ᠠᡵᠠᡥᠠ ᠰᡠᠨᠵᠠ ᡥᠠᠴᡳᠨ ᡳ ᡥᡝᡵᡤᡝᠨ ᡴᠠᠮᠴᡳᡥᠠ ᠮᠠᠨᠵᡠ ᡤᡳᠰᡠᠨ ᡳ ᠪᡠᠯᡝᡴᡠ ᠪᡳᡨ᠌ᡥᡝ᠈|lang=mnc|style=height:40px; word-wrap: normal;}}|v=han-i araha sunja hacin-i hergen kamciha manju gisun-i buleku bithe|a=han-i araha sunja haqin-i hergen kamqiha manju gisun-i buleku bithe}}, "dictionary of Manchu words written by the Emperor (i.e., by imperial order) containing five languages". The translations into the other languages are as follows: * Tibetan: ::''rgyal pos mdzad pa’i skad lnga shan sbyar yi manydzu’i skad gsal ba’i me long''
{{bo-textonly|རྒྱལ་པོས་མཛད་པའི་སྐད་ལྔ་ཤན་སྦྱར་གྱི་མཉཛུའི་སྐད་གསལ་བའི་མེ་ལོང་།}} * Mongolian: ::''qaɣan-u bičigsen tabun ǰüil-ün üsüg-iyer qabsuruɣsan manǰu ügen-ü toli bičig''
{{MongolUnicode|ᠬᠠᠭᠠᠨ ᠤ ᠪᠢᠴᠢᠭᠰᠡᠨ ᠲᠠᠪᠤᠨ ᠵᠦᠢᠯ ᠦᠨ ᠦᠰᠦᠭ ᠢᠶᠡᠷ ᠬᠠᠪᠰᠤᠷᠤᠭᠰᠠᠨ ᠮᠠᠨᠵᠤ ᠦᠭᠡᠨ ᠦ ᠲᠣᠯᠢ ᠪᠢᠴᠢᠭ᠌᠈|lang=mn|style=height:50px; word-wrap: normal;}}{{cite book|title=Approches contrastives en lexicographie bilingue / sous la direction de Thomas Szende.|volume=Volume 2 of Bibliothèque de l'INALF. Études de Lexicologie, Lexicographie et Dictionnairique|author=|editor-first=Tamás|editor-last=Szende|others=Contributor Institut national des langues et civilisations orientales|year=2000|publisher=Honoré Champion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RDliAAAAMAAJ&q=yuzhi+wuti&dq=yuzhi+wuti&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Qm9cVNmtA7SBsQSw4IL4Dw&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAjgK|page=25|isbn=2745304119|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} * Chagatai: ::''ḫān-nïng fütügän beš qismi qošqan ḫat mānjū söz-ning ayrïmčïn ḫati''
{{lower|{{script/Nastaliq| خان نينک فوتوکن بش قڛمی قوشقان خت مانجو ڛوزنينک ايری مجين ختی}}}} ==Structure== The Yuzhi Wuti Qing Wenjian is organized into six boxes, containing 36 volumes on 2563 pages. The original work contained 32 volumes, with a four-volume supplement. It is divided into divisions (such as "Heaven Division"), category (such as "Astronomy"), with the categories further separated into types. There are 56 divisions, 318 categories, 616 types, with a total of 18671 terms. Each term has eight rows. From the top, the rows contain Manchu, Tibetan, a mechanical Tibetan transliteration into Manchu, a [[phonetic]] Tibetan transcription into Manchu, Mongolian, [[Chagatai language|Chagatai]], a transcription of Chagatai into Manchu, and Chinese. For some terms, synonyms were included in the target languages (except Chinese). Thus, there are 19503 terms used in Mongolian corresponding to 18145 terms in Chinese (with 526 synonyms noted in Chinese). The '''Manchu''' text was largely based on the [[Manchu language#Beijing dialect of Manchu|Beijing dialect of Manchu]], using vertical regular script, with sentences terminated with punctuation ({{MongolUnicode|᠈ |valign=middle}}), but no subsidiary pronunciation marks. '''Tibetan''' used the common written Tibetan usage at the time, in horizontal script in [[Uchen script]] ({{Bo-textonly|དབུ་མེད་}}), with terms that could not be written into a single line divided at syllabic boundaries, and terminating punctuation marks ({{Bo-textonly|།}}). Under the Tibetan was the Manchu transliteration, using Manchu phonemes to transliterate Tibetan letters to allow two-way transliteration and using distinctive characters for initial and medial phonemes; further, to transliterate some Tibetan letters, some new written forms for Manchu phonemes were invented (including initial "ng" and terminal vowels). Below the Manchu transliteration was the Manchu transcription to record the pronunciation in the [[Central Tibetan language|Lhasa/Ü-Tsang dialect]], due to the [[diglossia|substantial difference]] between [[Classical Tibetan|written Tibetan]] and [[Tibetic languages|spoken Tibetan]]. For '''Mongolian''', the common written Mongolian of that time was used, in horizontal regular script, with punctuation marks at the end ({{MongolUnicode|᠈ |valign=middle}}). Chagatai is written horizontally in [[Nastaʿlīq script]], with terms that could not be written into a single line divided at syllabic boundaries and no terminal punctuations. Below Chagatai was Manchu transcription to record the [[Turpan Depression|eastern Xinjiang]] Turkic pronunciation,as opposed to Southern Xinjiang ([[Tarim Basin]]) and Northern Xinjiang ([[Dzungaria]]) due to the substantial difference between Chagatai and the spoken language of Xingjiang at the time; the sounds showed characteristics of the pronunciations used in the [[Hami Prefecture|Hami]]/[[Turpan]] regions;{{Cite journal|script-title=zh:《五体清文鉴》编纂过程及维吾尔文辞条研究概述|journal=《和田师范专科学校学报（汉文综合版）》|year=July 2005|volume=第25卷第三期总第35期|language=zh}} '''Chinese''' was spelled in traditional Chinese characters, also in vertical regular script, with the diction showing the influence of common usage in the [[Beijing dialect|Beijing Mandarin]] dialect. No punctuation or pronunciation marks were used. Below were the renderings of the first term, "Heaven," on the first page of the first section, "Astronomy": {| class="wikitable" ! explanation !! entry !! Latin transcription |----- | 1. Entry in Manchu || {{ManchuSibeUnicode|ᠠᠪᡴᠠ᠈|lang=mnc}} || ''abka'' |----- | 2. Tibetan translation || {{bo-textonly|གནམ།}} || ''gnam'' |----- | 3. Transliteration of Tibetan into Manchu letters || {{MongolUnicode|ᡤᠨᠠᠮ|lang=mnc}} || ''gnam'' |----- | 4. Transcription of the Tibetan pronunciation in Manchu script || {{MongolUnicode|ᠨᠠᠮ|lang=mnc}} || ''nam'' |----- | 5. Translation into Mongolian || {{MongolUnicode|ᠲᠨᠭᠷᠢ᠈|lang=mn}} || ''t[e]ngri'' |----- | 6. Translation into Chagatai || {{script/Nastaliq|آڛمان}} || ''āsmān'' |----- | 7. Transcription of Chagatai in Manchu script || {{MongolUnicode|ᠠᠰᠮᠠᠨ|lang=mnc}} || ''asman'' |----- | 8. Translation into Chinese || 天 || ''tiān'' |} ==Manuscripts and editions== The ''Yu Zhi Wu Ti Qing Wen Jian'' has been transmitted in three known [[manuscript]]s, held by the Beijing [[Palace Museum]], the [[Yonghe Temple]], and the [[British Museum]] in London. A print edition doesn’t seem to exist. In 1957, the Ethnic Publishing House (Nationalities Publishing House, Minzu Chubanshe, 民族出版社) published a photo-mechanic reproduction of the dictionary, which was reprinted in 1998. In 1967, Japanese scholars recompiled the ''Yu Zhi Wu Ti Qing Wen Jian'' and added Latin transliteration into a work known as the ''Interpretation of the Wuti Qing Wenjian''. In 1967, an edition was published in [[Japan]] that added transliterations of Manchu, the Manchu transcriptions of the other languages and a Japanese translation. In 2013, a critical edition with complete transliterations as well as indices for all five languages was published in [[Germany]]. * Tamura Jitsuzō 田村 實造, Imanishi Shunjū 今西 春秋, Satō Hisashi 佐藤 長 (Hg.): ''Gotai Shinbun kan yakukai'' 五體淸文鑑譯解. Kyōto, Kyōto daigaku bungakubu nairiku Ajia kenkyūjo 京都大學文學部內陸アジア硏究所 Shōwa 41–43 [1966–1968]. * Oliver Corff, Kyoko Maezono, Wolfgang Lipp, Dorjpalam Dorj, Görööchin Gerelmaa, Aysima Mirsultan, Réka Stüber, Byambajav Töwshintögs, Xieyan Li (eds.): ''Auf kaiserlichen Befehl erstelltes Wörterbuch des Manjurischen in fünf Sprachen. „Fünfsprachenspiegel“. Systematisch angeordneter Wortschatz auf Manjurisch, Tibetisch, Mongolisch, Turki und Chinesisch.'' Wiesbaden, Harrassowitz 2013, {{ISBN|978-3-447-06970-0}}. The ''Yu Zhi Wu Ti Qing Wen Jian'' is based on the ''Yu Zhi Si Ti Qing Wen Jian'' 御製四體清文鑑 ("Imperially-Published Four-Script Textual Mirror of Qing"), with Chagatai added as fifth language.{{cite book|title=Chinese Lexicography : A History from 1046 BC to AD 1911: A History from 1046 BC to AD 1911|issue=|first1=Heming|last1=Yong|first2=Jing|last2=Peng|editor-first=|editor-last=|edition=|year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NYFBtTUZFxEC&pg=PA398#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=398|isbn=0191561673|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} The four-language version of the dictionary with Tibetan was in turn based on an earlier three-language version with Manchu, Mongolian, and Chinese called the ''Yu Zhi Manzhu Menggu Hanzi San He Jieyin Qingwen Jian'' 御製滿珠蒙古漢字三合切音清文鑑 ("Imperially-Published Manchu Mongol Chinese Three pronunciation explanation mirror of Qing"), which was in turn based on the ''Yu Zhi Zengding Qingwen Jian'' 御製增訂清文鑑 ("Imperially-Published Revised and Enlarged mirror of Qing") in Manchu and Chinese, which used both Manchu script to transcribe Chinese words and [[Transcription into Chinese characters|Chinese characters to transcribe]] Manchu words with [[fanqie]].{{cite book|title=Chinese Lexicography : A History from 1046 BC to AD 1911: A History from 1046 BC to AD 1911|issue=|first1=Heming|last1=Yong|first2=Jing|last2=Peng|editor-first=|editor-last=|edition=|year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NYFBtTUZFxEC&pg=PA397#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=397|isbn=0191561673|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} In Mongol the title of 御製滿珠蒙古漢字三合切音清文鑑 is "(Qaɣan-u bicigsen) Manzu Mongɣol Kitad üsüg ɣurban züil-ün ajalɣu nejilegsen toli bicig".{{cite book|title=Etudes Mongoles et Sibériennes 16|author=Centre d'études mongoles et sibériennes|publisher=SEMS|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0I7ML6rrzN0C&pg=PA67&dq=yuzhi+wuti&hl=en&sa=X&ei=u2xcVKO0DcnGsQSDy4GIBw&ved=0CCkQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=yuzhi%20wuti&f=false|page=67|isbn=|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} In Manchu the title of 御製增訂清文鑑 is "Han-i araha nonggime toktobuha Manju gisun-i buleku bithe".[http://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/mulu/fcman.html Wade Collection Manchu Books]{{cite book|title=Central Asiatic Journal, Volume 36|author=|year=1992|publisher=O. Harrassowitz|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1fw-AQAAIAAJ&q=yuzhi+wuti&dq=yuzhi+wuti&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_m5cVLuMH83LsAS9r4DQCA&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBw|page=108|isbn=|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} It was used in [[Eight Banners|banner]] schools as a textbook.{{cite book|title=Printing and Book Culture in Late Imperial China|volume=Volume 27 of Studies on China|issue=|editor1-first=Cynthia J.|editor1-last=Brokaw|editor2-first=Kai-Wing|editor2-last=Chow|edition=|year=2005|publisher=University of California Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NkH2zGNRmkAC&pg=PA315&lpg=PA315&dq=yuzhi+wuti&source=bl&ots=KvXimbQ8JL&sig=BSkpS1GMue_oK6wvoMJEfIe5W_k&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KFpaVOKCGrbfsASN7ILQCg&ved=0CC0Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=yuzhi%20wuti&f=false|page=315|isbn=0520927796|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} A tetraglot dictionary (Yuzhi zengding Qingwen jian) in manuscript form exists in the Harvard-Yenching Library, where black ink is used for Chinese and Manchu and red ink for Tibetan and Mongolian.{{cite book|title=Treasures of the Yenching: Seventy-fifth Anniversity of the Harvard-Yenching Library : Exhibition Catalogue|issue=Issue 1 of Harvard-Yenching Library studies|author=Harvard-Yenching Library|editor-first=Patrick|editor-last=Hanan|others=Contributor Mikael S. Adolphson|year=2003|publisher=Chinese University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OksPvlsQOZEC&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88&dq=yuzhi+wuti&source=bl&ots=9-xBNRNtfq&sig=1uez73F11SUPpjkRyu0jRmVNuq0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=sBJcVJnPDuvIsASqiYKACw&ved=0CDUQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=yuzhi%20wuti&f=false|page=88|isbn=9629961024|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} In 1708 the ''Yu Zhi Qingwen Jian'' 御制清文鉴 "han-i araha manju gisun buleku bithe" was published.{{cite book|title=Books in Numbers: Seventy-fifth Anniversary of the Harvard-Yenching Library : Conference Papers|issue=Issue 8 of Harvard-Yenching Library studies|author=|editor-first=Wilt L.|editor-last=Idema|others=Contributor Lucille Chia|year=2007|publisher=Chinese University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=93onvmXF1r0C&pg=PA200&lpg=PA200&dq=yuzhi+wuti&source=bl&ots=Q2JMC5_cjc&sig=npuNrL92Yu_pl_lggpzCLDGWA0Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=aUBcVKW5EPiNsQTx74CADw&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=yuzhi%20wuti&f=false|page=200|isbn=9629963310|accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }}[http://www.dictall.com/indu/339/33892396291.htm 您的位置：首页 -> 词典 -> 《五体清文鉴》] "gamma uc̆in nigen boti, orosil nigen boti".{{cite book|title=御製滿珠蒙古漢字三合切音清文鉴: gamma uc̆in nigen boti, orosil nigen boti|edition=|year=1780|publisher=武英殿|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iTh6tgAACAAJ&dq=清文&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0-f_UqiFGsKIyAGmkIHQCw&ved=0CCgQ6AEwADgU |accessdate=24 April 2014| ref=harv }} ==See also== * [[Hua-Yi yiyu]] [[w:zh:華夷譯語]] ("Sino-Barbarian Dictionary") - a series of bilingual Chinese-foreign language dictionaries in [[Jurchen language|Jurchen]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Ryukyuan languages|Ryukyuan]], [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]], [[Old Uyghur language|Old Uyghur]], [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]], [[Cham language|Cham]], [[Tai Nüa language|Dai]], [[Thai language|Thai]], [[Burmese language|Burmese]], [[Khmer language|Khmer]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Classical Tibetan|Tibetan]], [[Malay language|Malay]], [[Javanese language|Javanese]], [[Acehnese language|Acehnese]], and [[Sanskrit]] * [[Yuding Xiyu Tongwen Zhi]] 欽定西域同文志 ("Imperial Western Regions Thesaurus")- a thesaurus of geographical names in Xinjiang in revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Pixabay | logo = Pixabay-logo.svg | logo_size = 215px | url = {{URL|http://pixabay.com|pixabay.com}} | type = Public domain imagery | language = [[Multilingualism|Multilingual]] (26) | author = {{plainlist | * Hans Braxmeier, * Simon Steinberger }} | launch_date = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2010|11|24}} | alexa = 501 ({{as of|2016|14|9|alt=September 2017}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/pixabay.com |title= Pixabay.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2017-09-14 }}</ref> | current_status = Active | owner = Hans Braxmeier & Simon Steinberger GbR }}
'''Pixabay.com''' is an international website for sharing high quality [[public domain]] photos, illustrations, [[vector graphic]]s, and film footage. As of November 2017, Pixabay offers over 1,188,454 free photos, illustrations, and vectors and videos.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pixabay.com/ |title=Pixabay home page |publisher=Pixabay.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-03}}</ref>
== History == The enterprise was founded in November 2011 in [[Ulm]], [[Germany]] by Hans Braxmeier and Simon Steinberger. In March 2012, Pixabay was redesigned, switching from a personal image collection into an interactive [[online community]], supporting 20 languages. In May of the same year, a public Application Programming Interface ([[API]]) was launched, allowing third party users and website developers to search Pixabay's image database. Today, the API is being used by the designer community Psykopaint, and inside [[Jimdo]]'s [[WYSIWYG]] homepage editor. Along with [[Flickr]], [[YouTube]] and [[Wikimedia Commons]], in June 2012, Pixabay was included on [[Creative Commons]]' official CC search site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.creativecommons.org/|title=CC Search|publisher=}}</ref> On a regular basis, Pixabay received attention in international print and online magazines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noupe.com/freebie/pixabay-more-than-40-000-completely-free-photos-and-illustrations-73034.html |title=Pixabay: More Than 40,000 Completely Free Photos And Illustrations |publisher=Noupe |date=2012-11-05 |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gigazine.net/news/20121108-public-domain-pixabay/ |title=商用・非商用を問わず完全フリーで使えるハイクオリティな画像検索サイト「Pixabay」 |publisher=Gigazine |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hvg.hu/tudomany/20130205_65_ezer_ingyenes_korlatozas_nelkul_letolt |title=HVG - 65 ezer ingyenes, korlátozás nélkül letölthető fantasztikus kép |publisher=Hvg.hu |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/webwelt/article106605938/Das-sind-die-besten-kostenlosen-Fotodatenbanken.html |title=Das sind die besten kostenlosen Fotodatenbanken |publisher=Welt.de |date=2011-11-23 |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Von Rainer Schuldt, 14.06.2012, 19:00 Uhr |url=http://www.computerbild.de/artikel/cb-Ratgeber-Kurse-Internet-Bilder-und-Fotos-zum-Nulltarif-7569805.html#1 |title=Tolle Bilder zum Nulltarif |publisher=Computerbild.de |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://de.nachrichten.yahoo.com/fotos/6-datenbanken-mit-gratis-bildern-slideshow/pixabay-com-photo-1345616264.html |title=Yahoo Nachrichten - 6 Datenbanken mit Gratis-Bildern |publisher=De.nachrichten.yahoo.com |date=2011-04-20 |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref><ref>Page 12/2012, "Low-Budget-Bildquellen", p. 70-74, www.page-online.de</ref> In 2014, six additional interface languages were implemented (Thai, Vietnamese, Greek, Slovak, Bulgarian, Danish) and in 2015, Pixabay started offering film footage in addition to images - all of which released under [[Creative Commons license]] [[CC0]].
== Description == On Pixabay, users can find and contribute quality images and footage films free of [[copyright]]s. For uploading files and downloading full sized images, a free registration is required. By uploading files, the contributors waive their copyright and related image rights under Creative Commons deed [[CC0]], thus permitting free usage of their work. Consequently, anyone is allowed to use, modify and redistribute the images freely - even in commercial applications - without asking for permission and without accreditation.
Depicted content may yet be protected by trademarks, publicity or privacy rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pixabay.com/ro/blog/posts/public-domain-images-what-is-allowed-and-what-is-4/|title=Public Domain Images - What is allowed and what is not?|publisher=}}</ref> To ensure a high quality standard and avoid legal issues, all uploaded images are checked manually by Pixabay's staff members.
==Quality standards for contributors== Image contributors must respect Pixabay's quality standards: The image file format must be [[JPEG]], [[Portable Network Graphics|PNG]], [[.psd|PSD]], [[Adobe Illustrator Artwork|AI]], or [[SVG]] and the file size may not be over 40 MB. Furthermore, all newly submitted images must have at least 3000 px at one side; they must show something useful and have no obvious technical flaws.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=https://pixabay.com/ro/photos/tools/quality_rating/|title=Autentificare|publisher=}}</ref>
Footage can be uploaded in [[MPEG]], [[QuickTime File Format|MOV]] and [[Audio Video Interleave|AVI]] format and file sizes may not surpass 300 MB. A minimum resolution of 1280×800 pixels is required, and clips should not exceed 60 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pixabay.com/ro/blog/posts/video-quality-guidelines-68/|title=Video Quality Guidelines|publisher=}}</ref>
==Photographers== In January 2016, there were about 33,200 active image authors. Hans Braxmeier himself contributed over 20,000 images, which were downloaded over two million times. The second most active contributor was geralt, who uploaded 10,000 images (over 4,5 million downloads).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pixabay.com/en/users/?order=popular|title=Top 100 photographers|publisher=}}</ref>
==Staff== Hans Braxmeier - founder and CEO of Pixabay - has studied computer science in [[Ulm]], Germany. During and after his studies, he launched several other web projects.
Simon Steinberger - co-founder and also CEO of Pixabay - studied chemistry in Ulm and finished his PhD in 2011. During this time, he started working in the IT sector and developed various other websites.
Achim Thiemermann is responsible for social media marketing and Olga Foma focuses on image quality control.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pixabay.com/en/service/imprint/|title=About Us|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191404/https://pixabay.com/en/service/imprint/|archivedate=2016-03-04|df=}}</ref>
==Popularity== Pixabay was ranked 501st on Alexa on September 14, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/pixabay.com|title=pixabay.com Site Overview|publisher=}}</ref> Google assigned the domain a PageRank of six.
==Visitors and users== About 27% of Pixabay's visitors speak English, 20% Spanish, 11% Portuguese, 7% German, and 5% speak French. Users are mainly bloggers, graphics designers, authors, journalists and advertisers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/pixabay.com# |title=Alexa / Unpublished data based on Google Analytics |publisher=Alexa.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref>
== Technology == Pixabay's backend is written in the [[Python (programming language)|Python]] based web framework [[Django (web framework)|Django]], running on an [[Nginx]] server with [[PostgreSQL]] as database system. The internal search is working on a [[Lucene]] based [[ElasticSearch]] server.<ref name="technology">{{cite web|url=http://pixabay.com/de/blog/posts/pixabay-powered-by-new-server-15/ |title=Pixabay powered by new server |language=de |publisher=Pixabay.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.webtechster.com/pixabay.com|title = Pixabay.com Technology Profile| publisher = WebTechster | accessdate = 2014-03-27}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = PriceGrabber.com, LLC | logo = PriceGrabber Logo.jpg | type = Subsidiary | genre = | foundation = 1999 | founder = Tamim Mourad
Kamran Pourzanjani | location_city = [[Los Angeles, California]] | location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Steve Krenzer, CEO
Jeff Goldstein, President, Rojeh Avanesian, SVP of Sales and Marketing
Dominique Jean, CTO | industry = Internet Services : Comparison Shopping : Distributed Content Commerce | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | divisions = | subsid = | caption = Smart Shopping Anytime Anywhere | homepage = [http://www.pricegrabber.com/ pricegrabber.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''PriceGrabber'''.com is a price-comparison shopping site and distributed content commerce service founded in 1999 by former CEOs Kamran Pourzanjani and Tamim Mourad. The company partners with merchants, retailers, and sellers to provide information on a wide range of products. PriceGrabber.com was the first comparison-shopping engine to project tax and shipping cost information for a consumer during the price comparison process.http://www.pricegrabber.com/about.php/about=press/sub_opt=14/year_opt=1/article=1 == Acquisitions == In 2005, PriceGrabber was acquired by [[Experian]] for $485 million, negotiated by then-CEO and founder of the company, [[Kamran Pourzanjani]], along with Tamim Mourad, in 1999.[https://www.forbes.com/home/feeds/afx/2005/12/14/afx2390699.html Forbes] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051216080349/http://www.forbes.com/home/feeds/afx/2005/12/14/afx2390699.html |date=December 16, 2005 }}{{cite web|title=Experian Buys PriceGrabber.com For $485 Million|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB113456544561122262|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=20 December 2017|date=14 December 2005}} In 2012, Experian agreed to sell PriceGrabber at a significant loss to Indian group Ybrant Digital.{{cite web|title=Experian sells businesses at less than quarter of cost|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/9257407/Experian-sells-businesses-at-less-than-quarter-of-cost.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=20 December 2017|date=10 May 2012}} After the sale fell through,{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Duncan|title=Experian’s PriceGrabber sale falls through|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ab25ea82-07b3-11e2-9df2-00144feabdc0|website=Financial Times|accessdate=20 December 2017|date=26 September 2012}} Experian announced in October of that year that it had completed the sale of PriceGrabber, LowerMyBills, and ClassesUSA.com to the management team of those businesses for an undisclosed amount.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} In June 2015, Connexity (formerly [[Shopzilla]]) announced it had purchased PriceGrabber, Inc. for an undisclosed amount.{{cite web|url=http://connexity.com/blog/2015/06/connexity-acquires-pricegrabber/|title=Connexity Acquires PriceGrabber - Official Press Release|date=15 June 2015|publisher=|accessdate=9 October 2017}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.pricegrabber.com/}} *[http://www.pricegrabber.co.uk/ PriceGrabber UK] *[http://www.pricegrabber.ca/ PriceGrabber CA] {{DEFAULTSORT:Pricegrabber}} [[Category:Comparison shopping websites]] {{commerce-website-stub}}

page.title: Publication of Archival, Library & Museum Materials

revision.comment: Successfully de-orphaned! Wikiproject Orphanage: [[Wikipedia:ORPHAN|You can help!]]
revision.text:
'''Publication of Archival, Library & Museum Materials''' ('''PALMM''') is a cooperative initiative of the public universities of [[Florida]] in the United States to provide a central repository for smaller digital collections.<ref>[http://palmm.fcla.edu Publication of Archival, Library & Museum Materials], [http://www.fcla.edu/ Florida Center for Library Automation], USA.</ref> In addition to contributing to PALMM, universities in Florida also host and maintain separate individual [[digital collection]]s as well as many large collaborative projects. In September 2011, Florida's Council of State University Libraries selected [[SobekCM]] to power a common digital library system across the state, replacing the software currently powering the PALMM collections.
Other large, collaborate digital libraries supported by public universities in Florida include:
*[[Florida International University]], which hosts and supports the [[Everglades Digital Library]] *[[Digital Library of the Caribbean]], with many contributing partners in Florida and the Caribbean<ref>[http://dloc.com/ Digital Library of the Caribbean]</ref> *[[University of South Florida]], which hosts and supports the Florida Oral History Digital Collections *[[University of Central Florida]], which hosts and supports Central Florida Memory<ref>[http://www.cfmemory.org/ Central Florida Memory], [[University of Central Florida]], USA.</ref> *[[University of Florida]], which hosts and supports [[Florida Digital Newspaper Library]]<ref>[http://ufdc.ufl.edu/newspapers Florida Digital Newspaper Library], [[University of Florida]], USA.</ref> *[[University of Florida]], which hosts and supports the [[University of Florida Digital Collections]]<ref>[http://ufdc.ufl.edu/ University of Florida Digital Collections], [[University of Florida]], USA.</ref>
== Collections ==
=== Archives Florida === Archives Florida is a database of guides and inventories (finding aids) for Florida archive collections. Finding aids can be contributed by Florida libraries, museums, historical societies, and other groups. The database is constantly updated, and users can browse or search collectively or by individual archives.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://palmm2.fcla.edu/afl/|title = Archives Florida|date = |accessdate = |website = Publication of Archival Library & Museum Materials|publisher = State University System of Florida|last = |first = }}</ref> Contributing libraries and museums include Broward County Library, Florida Atlantic University Libraries, Florida International University Libraries, Florida State University, Rollins College, and Winter Park Public Library.
=== Aerial Photography Florida === With approximately 160,000 photos, the Aerial Photography: Florida Collection is the largest and most complete collection of Florida aerial photographs outside of the [[National Archives and Records Administration|National Archives]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://ufdc.ufl.edu/aerials/?n=palmm|title = Aerial Photography: Florida|date = |accessdate = |website = UFDC|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The photographs center on the changes in Florida's land use spanning the years of 1937 to 1990. This online collection was funded by three Library Services and Technology Act grants. Users can search using map search, flights by county, and ArcGIS search. Additionally, images can be downloaded as [[JPEG 2000]] files.
Aerial photography has been used as an educational resource, enabling farmers to better utilize their land and informing city planners in their decision-making process.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://ufdc.ufl.edu/aerials/teachers|title = Teachers|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = University of Florida George A. Smathers Libraries|last = |first = }}</ref>
=== Big Cypress National Preserve Collection === Documenting the natural heritage of the [[Big Cypress National Preserve]], the Big Cypress National Preserve Collection serves as a digital photo-album showing the flora and fauna of this preserve in southwestern Florida.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://palmm.fcla.edu/cypress/|title = Big Cypress National Preserve|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = Publication of Archival Library & Museum Materials|last = |first = }}</ref> The collection was produced by the Preserve's staff alongside the Southwest Florida Library Network (SWFLN) in a project funded by the State of Florida's Library Services and Technology Act (LSTA) grants program.
=== Coral Gables Memory === Donated to the city of [[Coral Gables, Florida|Coral Gables]] by Kerdyk Realty, Coral Gables Memory is an album that contains photographs of homes and business structures. Coral Gables is a planned community that took much inspiration from the Garden City and City Beautiful movements of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://miami.fiu.edu/coralgables/index.htm|title = Coral Gables Memory|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = Publication of Archival Library & Museum Materials|last = |first = }}</ref>
Most of the photographs in Coral Gables Memory collection were captured in the 1940s. Users will find visual and textual materials that document the history, culture, architecture, and people of Coral Gables. Additionally, minute books, published works, postcards, among other materials, can be viewed in this collection.
=== Everglades Digital Library === Established in 1996, the [[Everglades Digital Library]] (EDL) features online texts, articles, reports, photographs, maps, data sets, educational materials, and historical records all pertaining to the South Florida environment. The primary goal of this collection is to support research, education, decision making, and information resource management within the greater Everglades community. The materials within this collection originate from such sources as libraries, government agencies, non-profit organizations, and educational institutions. The EDL is a service of the Digital Collections Center at Florida International University Libraries.
In terms of technology, the EDL runs on the Collection Workflow Integration System (CWIS), which was specifically created to help build collections in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math for the National Science Digital Library. Because of this system, the EDL enjoys many features, including [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] resource annotations and ratings, keyword searching, RSS feed support, an integrated metadata editing tool, prepackaged taxonomies, user-definable schema, and even user interface themes.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://cwis.fcla.edu/edl/index.php?P=About|title = About Everglades Digital Library|date = |accessdate = |website = Everglades Digital Library|publisher = Florida International University Libraries|last = |first = }}</ref>
=== Florida Heritage Collection === Established in 1998 by the libraries of the State University System of Florida (SUS) in partnership with the Florida Center for Library Automation (FCLA) and the State Library of Florida, the Florida Heritage Collection is the first statewide digital library initiative in Florida. This collection is notable in that it provides online access to materials broadly representing Florida’s history, culture, arts, literature, sciences and social sciences. Some of the major focuses of the Florida Heritage Collection are Native American and minority populations, exploration and development, tourism, the natural environment, and regional interests. Florida's ten state universities contribute materials from their archives, special collections, and libraries to this collection.
Users viewing this collection will find a variety of local and regional materials about Florida's history and cultural, including local history books and booklets, advertising materials from the Florida Boom, Civil War letters, and other materials that provide knowledge of Florida's history. Due to the largely emigrant nature of Florida's history, the collection stresses the importance of featuring family papers and records, diaries, letters, business records, maps, photographs, and other materials that are unique and important for historical research.
In terms of workflow, the contributing university libraries and archives contribute catalog records for the digitized version to a central database. For each submission, libraries indicate the grade level of the material in accordance with Florida's [[Sunshine State Standards]].
=== Miami Metropolitan Archive === Developed in 2001, the Miami Metropolitan Archive is focused on preserving and sharing early Miami materials. The themes of this collection are local history, community development, urban planning and design, resource and environmental management, area studies, architecture, transportation, education, Black Miami, and multicultural issues. Miami Metropolitan Archive's goal is to provide digital access to important source materials on Miami-Dade County urban development. The Miami Metropolitan Archive is operated by the Urban, Regional & Local Government Documents Department at Florida International University Libraries and Miami City Clerk's Office.
For the years of 1896 to 1966, users will find government documents, including Miami City Council meeting minutes, charters, departmental annual reports, and planning documents.
=== Florida Historical Quarterly === An online version of the academic journal by the same title, the goal of the Florida Historical Quarterly is to expand users' understanding of Florida's historical development. This collection emphasizes scholarly research and appreciation for the peoples, places, themes, and diversity of Florida's past.
Although the Florida Historical Quarterly was originally a part of the Florida Heritage Collection, in 2005 the Digital Projects Planning Committee decided to separate it into its own individual collection because of its high volume of use and the need for direct access.
=== Koreshan State Historic Site Collection === The Koreshan State Historic Site Collection focuses on the [[Koreshan State Historic Site]], one of Florida's state parks and a cultural heritage site. This collection serves as a digital photo-album of the site. The photographs within this collection were contributed by the Estero Historical Society and the Florida Division of Recreation and Parks - Koreshan State Historic Site.
The collection is funded by the Library Services and Technology Act Grants (LSTA).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://palmm.fcla.edu/ PALMM website] *[http://www.fcla.edu/ Florida Center for Library Automation] *[http://www.fcla.edu/digitalArchive/ Florida Digital Archive]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Publication of Archival, Library and Museum Materials}} [[Category:University and college academic libraries in the United States]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Florida]] [[Category:Education in Florida]] [[Category:Collections of museums in the United States]] [[Category:Online archives]]

'''REGISTRAR-LOCK''' is a status code that can be set on an Internet [[domain name]] by the sponsoring [[domain name registrar|registrar]] of the domain name.<ref name="RFC2832">{{IETF RFC|2832}} - NSI Registry Registrar Protocol (RRP) Version 1.1.0</ref><ref>{{IETF RFC|3632}} - VeriSign Registry Registrar Protocol (RRP) Version 2.0.0</ref> This is usually done in order to prevent unauthorized, unwanted or accidental changes to the domain name.
When set, the following actions are prohibited by the [[domain name registry]]: * '''Modification''' of the domain name, including: ** '''Transferring''' of the domain name ** '''Deletion''' of the domain name * '''Modification''' of the domain contact details
Renewal of the domain name is, however, still possible when REGISTRAR-LOCK is set.
Not all [[Top-level domains]] (TLDs) support REGISTRAR-LOCK,{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} e.g. .org.uk, and others.
The [[.ca]] TLD added support for REGISTRAR-LOCK in October 2010.
{{IETF RFC|2832}}, section 6, and {{IETF RFC|3632}}, section 2.1, lists the different status codes and their descriptions.
==See also== * [[Domain privacy]] * [[Domain slamming]] * [[Transfer secret]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Domain name system]]
{{Compu-domain-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{original research|date=September 2018}}{{one source|date=September 2018}}{{technical|date=September 2018}}}}
'''Sidi Lakhmi mausoleum''' or '''Sidi Abi Al Hassan Lakhmi mausoleum''' ([[Arabic]]: زاوية سيدي أبي الحسن اللخمي) is one the most important [[mausoleum]]s of the [[medina of Sfax]]. It is located outside the walls of the city.
== History == According to the inscription at the entrance of the mausoleum, the monument was built in the 17th century during the reign of the [[Muradid dynasty]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Abi Al Hassan Al Lakhmi in the memory of Sfax|last=Ben Chaabene|first=Nihed|publisher=|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=69–77}}</ref> six centuries after the death of the saint Sidi Abu El Hassan El Lakhami in 1085. Initially, he was first buried in the old cemetery of Sfax (oldest cemetery in the city).
Over time, the mausoleum acquired important religious status and became a very important destination for prayer and seeking blessings for local communities in Sfax and adjacent. The building kept receiving visitors for centuries until its closure by the Tunisian authorities in 2011, after the [[Tunisian Revolution|revolution]].<ref name=":0" />
== Location == The Sidi Lakhmi's zaouia is located outside the walls of the medina, on the north side near [[Bab Jebli]], and just next to [[Sidi Lakhmi mosque]].
== Architecture == Before the construction of [[Sidi Lakhmi mosque]] (also called El Jedid mosque), access to the mausoleum was through a small entrance in front of [[Bab Jebli]] and opens onto a small court. This court has two side galleries: The first, on the eastern side, is based on a column and gives access to the bathroom, an [[Ablution in Islam|abultion]] room and a water-well. The second, on the western side, is composed of two arches and leads to a small rectangular room.<ref name=":0" />
The rectangular hall of the sanctuary is decorated with an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] style, and capitals with [[Hafsid dynasty|Hafsid]] style. It has a dome made of pottery tubes that help to reduce the total weight, and limestone corner blocks that ensure the transition from the square part of the basis to the circular one.
== References == <references />
[[Category:Medina of Sfax]] [[Category:Mausoleums]] [[Category:Islam]]
