revision.text: {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox software | name = WinSAT | logo = | logo caption = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | screenshot = | caption = | screenshot_size = | screenshot_alt = | collapsible = | developer = [[Microsoft]] | released = | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | status = | programming language = | operating system = {{Plainlist| * [[Windows Vista]] * [[Windows 7]] * [[Windows 8]] * [[Windows 8.1]] * [[Windows 10]] }} | platform = [[x86]], [[x86-64]] | size = | language = | language count = | language footnote = | genre = [[Computer performance]] measurement | license = | alexa = | website = [http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/cc948912%28v=vs.85%29.aspx Windows System Assessment Tool at MSDN] | standard = | AsOf = }} The '''Windows System Assessment Tool''' ('''WinSAT''') is a module of [[Microsoft]] [[Windows Vista]], [[Windows 7]], [[Windows 8]] and [[Windows 10]] that is available in the [[Control Panel (Windows)|Control Panel]] under ''Performance Information and Tools'' (except in [[Windows 8.1]] & [[Windows 10]]). It measures various performance characteristics and capabilities of the hardware it is running on and reports them as a '''Windows Experience Index (WEI)''' score. The WEI includes five subscores: processor, memory, 2D graphics, 3D graphics, and disk; the basescore is equal to the lowest of the subscores and is '''not''' an average of the subscores.{{cite web |title=Windows 7 WEI Scores 6.0 through 7.9 Explained|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/Windows-7-WEI-Scores-6-0-through-7-9-Explained-172277.shtml |publisher=Softpedia |accessdate=June 3, 2011}}{{cite web |title=Earning the top Windows Experience Index score |url=http://windows.microsoft.com/en-gb/windows7/achieving-a-perfect-windows-experience-index-score-in-windows-7 |publisher=Microsoft |accessdate=June 3, 2011}} WinSAT reports WEI scores on a scale from 1.0 to 5.9 for Windows Vista,[http://windowsvistablog.com/blogs/windowsvista/archive/2006/09/22/windows-experience-index-an-in-depth-look.aspx Vista Team Blog : Windows Experience Index: An In-Depth Look] 7.9 for Windows 7,{{cite web| url = http://www.pcworld.com/article/239713/how_to_max_out_your_windows_performance_for_1000.html |title = How to Max Out Your Windows Performance for $1000 | author = Marco Chiappetta |publisher = [[PC World]] | date = September 8, 2011 | accessdate=May 17, 2014}} and 9.9 for Windows 8 and Windows 10.{{cite web | url = http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/hh825488.aspx |title = WinSAT Comprehensive | date = October 20, 2013 | publisher = MSDN | accessdate=May 17, 2014}} The WEI enables users to match their computer hardware performance with the performance requirements of software. For example, the [[Windows Aero|Aero]] [[graphical user interface]] will not automatically be enabled unless the system has a WEI score of 3 or higher.{{cite web |title=Full screen previews have got disabled. How do I re-enable them? |url=http://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/windows_7-desktop/full-screen-previews-have-got-disabled-how-do-i-re/d44193c0-7e51-4a2f-8ec0-4ac115c710c0 |publisher=Microsoft |accessdate=June 3, 2011}}{{cite web |title=What Is the Windows Experience Index |url=http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/windows-vista/What-is-the-Windows-Experience-Index |publisher=Microsoft |accessdate=June 3, 2011}} The WEI can also be used to show which part of a system would be expected to provide the greatest increase in performance when upgraded. For example, a computer with the lowest subscore being its memory, would benefit more from a [[RAM]] upgrade than adding a faster hard drive (or any other component). Detailed raw performance information, like actual disk bandwidth, can be obtained by invoking winsat from the command line. This also allows only specific tests to be re-run.[http://windowsitpro.com/systems-management/winsat-command-line-utility Winsat Command-Line Utility] Obtaining the WEI score from the command line is done invoking winsat formal, which also updates the value stored in %systemroot%\Performance\WinSAT\DataStore.[http://windowsitpro.com/systems-management/how-can-i-run-windows-system-assessment-tool-winsat-update-directly-command-line How can I run the Windows System Assessment Tool (WinSAT) update directly from a command line?] (The XML files stored there can be easily hacked to report fake performance values.[http://www.howtogeek.com/71500/stupid-geek-tricks-hacking-the-windows-experience-index/ Stupid Geek Tricks: Hacking the Windows Experience Index]) The WEI is also available to applications through an [[API]], so they can configure themselves as a function of hardware performance, taking advantage of its capabilities without becoming unacceptably slow.{{cite web |title=Windows Experience Index: Overview |url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc507870.aspx |publisher=Microsoft TechNet |accessdate=September 24, 2011}} The Windows Experience Index score is not displayed in [[Windows 8.1]] and onwards because the [[graphical user interface]] for WinSAT was removed in these versions of Windows, although the [[command line]] winsat tool still exists and operates correctly along with a final score when launching the command "shell:games".{{cite web| url=http://www.cnet.com/how-to/find-your-windows-experience-index-scores-in-windows-8-1/| title=Find your Windows Experience Index scores in Windows 8.1 | author = Ed Rhee | date=January 2, 2014 | publisher=[[CNET]]| accessdate=May 17, 2014}} According to an article in [[PC Pro]], Microsoft removed the WinSAT GUI in order to promote the idea that all kinds of hardware run Windows 8 equally well.{{cite web| url = http://www.pcpro.co.uk/blogs/2013/09/19/farewell-to-the-windows-experience-index/ | date = September 19, 2013 | author = Darien Graham-Smith| title = Farewell to the Windows Experience Index | accessdate=May 17, 2014}} ==History== At the 2003 [[Game Developers Conference]] Dean Lester, Microsoft's General Manager of Windows Graphics and Gaming, stated in an interview with [[GameSpot]] that Microsoft intended to focus on improvements to the PC gaming experience as part of a new gaming initiative for the next version of Windows, [[Windows Vista]], then codenamed "Longhorn." Lester stated that as part of this initiative the operating system would include a [[Games for Windows#Games Explorer|games folder that would centralize settings pertinent to gamers]] and, among other features, [[Windows Display Driver Model|display driver streamlining]], [[Security and safety features new to Windows Vista#Parental controls|parental controls for games]] and the [[Games for Windows#Tray and Play|ability to start a Windows game directly from optical media]] during installation—in a manner similar to games designed for a [[video game console]]. Microsoft would also require a new method of displaying system requirements on retail packaging for Windows games with a rating system that would categorize games based on a numerical system.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/microsofts-big-pc-plans/1100-2912498/ |title=Microsoft's big PC plans |last=Parker |first=Sam |date=March 10, 2003 |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |work=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=August 10, 2015}} In 2004, Lester expanded further on Microsoft's intentions by stating that the company would work with hardware manufacturers to create PCs for Windows Vista that used a "level system" to designate the performance and capabilities of a system's hardware and that [[Xbox 360]] peripherals would be fully compatible with the operating system.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/microsoft-talks-longhorn-xna-and-xbox-2/1100-6108247/ |title=Microsoft talks Longhorn, XNA, and Xbox 2 |date=September 22, 2004 |author=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=April 18, 2015}} The Windows Experience Index feature in Windows Vista relies on measurements taken with WinSAT to provide an accurate assessment of a system's capabilities—these capabilities are presented in the form of a rating, where a higher rating indicates better performance. Preliminary design elements created for Microsoft by Robert Stein in 2004 suggest that WinSAT was intended to rate a user's hardware during the [[out-of-box experience]];{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/rs3art/304021764/in/set-72157594393542938 |title=Aurora for OOBE |last=Stein |first=Robert |work=[[Flickr]] |date=November 22, 2006 |accessdate=April 18, 2015}} this is a design decision that would be retained for the operating system's [[release to manufacturing]].{{cite web |url=http://download.microsoft.com/download/5/b/9/5b97017b-e28a-4bae-ba48-174cf47d23cd/cpa101_wh06.ppt |title=Windows Vista System Requirements and WinSAT |last=Russell |first=Richard |date=2006 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |format=PPT |accessdate=April 18, 2015}} During the [[Windows Hardware Engineering Conference]] of 2005, Microsoft formally unveiled the existence of WinSAT and presented it as a technology not only for games, but one that would allow Windows Vista to make decisions, such as whether to enable [[compositing window manager|desktop composition]], based on a machine's hardware capabilities.{{cite web |url=http://www.techrepublic.com/article/the-long-and-short-of-longhorns-hardware-requirements/ |title=The long and short of Longhorn's hardware requirements |last=Shultz |first=Greg |date=June 30, 2005 |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |work=[[TechRepublic]] |accessdate=April 18, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mikehall/archive/2005/04/26/412402.aspx |title=WinHEC : Chris Muench Report for Day 2 - Everything has two sides |last=Muench |first=Chris |date=April 26, 2005 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |work=MSDN Blogs |accessdate=April 18, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://download.microsoft.com/download/9/8/f/98f3fe47-dfc3-4e74-92a3-088782200fe7/TWAR05002_WinHEC05.ppt |title=System Performance Assessment Tools for Windows 'Longhorn' |last=Russell |first=Richard |date=2005 |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |format=PPT |accessdate=April 18, 2015}} WinSAT would remain a key focus throughout development of the operating system before its release to manufacturing. ==Tests== {{unreferenced section|date=March 2014}} WinSAT in Windows Vista and Windows 7 performs the following tests: * Direct3D 9 Aero Assessment * Direct3D 9 Batch Assessment * Direct3D 9 [[alpha compositing|Alpha Blend]] Assessment * Direct3D 9 [[texture mapping|Texture]] Load Assessment * Direct3D 9 [[arithmetic logic unit|ALU]] Assessment * Direct3D 10 Batch Assessment * Direct3D 10 Alpha Blend Assessment * Direct3D 10 Texture Load Assessment * Direct3D 10 ALU Assessment * Direct3D 10 Geometry Assessment * Direct3D 10 Constant Buffer Assessment * Windows Media Decoding Performance * Windows Media Encoding Performance * [[Central processing unit|CPU]] Performance * [[Computer storage|Memory]] Performance * [[Hard disk|Disk]] Performance (includes devices such as [[Solid-state drive]]s) While running, the tests show only a progress bar and a "working" background animation. Aero Glass is deactivated on Windows Vista and Windows 7 during testing so the tool can properly assess the graphics card and CPU. In Windows 8, WinSAT runs under the maintenance scheduler every week. The default schedule is 1am on Sundays. The maintenance scheduler collates various OS tasks into a schedule so the computer is not being randomly interrupted by the individual tasks. The scheduler wakes the computer from sleep, runs all the scheduled tasks and then puts the computer back to sleep. During this weekly task, WinSAT runs long enough to detect if there have been any hardware changes. If so, then the tests are run again. If not, then WinSAT simply ends as the existing scores must be valid. WinSAT cannot perform the above tests when a laptop is battery-operated. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-gb/library/ms737395.aspx WinSAT API] * [http://www.myfavoritegadgets.info/tipstricks/WEIwin81.html How To Get Windows Experience Index (WEI) Score In Windows 8.1] * [http://www.softwareok.com/?Microsoft/ExperienceIndexOK Freeware - get Windows Experience Index in Windows 8.1 and Windows 10] {{Windows Components}} {{Windows commands}} [[Category:Windows Vista|System Assessment Tool]] [[Category:Benchmarks (computing)]]

revision.comment: Minor punctuation and grammar changes.
revision.text:
{{Italic title}} [[File:2016-05-16 Yongle Enzyklopädie im Changling-Mausoleum anagoria.JPG|thumb|Pages of the ''Yongle Canon'' at the [[Ming tombs|Changling tombs]]]] The '''''Yongle Encyclopedia''''' or '''''Yongle Dadian''''' ({{zh|t=永樂大典|s=永乐大典|p=Yǒnglè Dàdiǎn|w=Yung-lo Ta-tien|l=Great Canon of Yongle}}) is a partially lost Chinese ''[[leishu]]'' [[encyclopedia]] commissioned by the [[Yongle Emperor]] of the [[Ming dynasty]] in 1403 and completed by 1408. Its sheer scope and size made it the world's largest paper-based general encyclopedia.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica|title=Encyclopedias and Dictionaries|edition=15th |year=2007 |volume=18|pages=257–286}}</ref>
==Background== Although known for his military achievements, the [[Yongle Emperor]] was also an intellectual who enjoyed reading.<ref name=":0">Christos, Lauren. "The Yongle Dadian: The Origin, Destruction, Dispersal, and Reclamation of a Chinese Cultural Treasure." ''Journal of Library and Information Science'' 36, no. 1 (April 2010): 85. <nowiki>http://140.122.104.2/ojs/index.php/jlis/article/view/538</nowiki>.</ref> His love for research led him to develop the idea of categorizing literary works into a reference [[encyclopedia]], in order to preserve rare books and simplify research.<ref name=":1">Jianying, Huo. "Emperor Yongle." ''China Today'', April 2004, 58.</ref><ref name=":2">Tsai, Shih-Shan Henry. Perpetual The Ming Emperor Yongle, University of Washington Press, 2011. ProQuest Ebook Central, <nowiki>https://ebookcentral-proquest-com.oca.ucsc.edu/lib/ucsc/detail.action?docID=3444272</nowiki>.</ref> Instrumental to this undertaking was Emperor Yongle’s own transformation of the [[Hanlin Academy]].<ref name=":1" /> Prior to his reign, the [[Hanlin Academy]] was responsible for various clerical tasks, such as drafting proclamations and edicts.<ref name=":1" /> Emperor Yongle, decided to elevate the status of the [[Hanlin Academy]], and began selecting only the highest ranking recruits for the academy.<ref name=":0" /> Clerical duties were relegated to the Imperial officers, while the [[Hanlin Academy]], now full of elite scholars, began working on literary projects for the Emperor.<ref name=":0" />
==Development== The ''Yongle Dadian'' was commissioned by the [[Yongle Emperor]] (r. 1402–24) and completed in 1408. [[File:Yongle.jpg|thumb|Yongle Emperor]]In 1404, a year after the work was commissioned, a team of 100 scholars, mostly from the [[Hanlin Academy]], completed a manuscript called ''[[A Complete Work of Literature]].''<ref name=":1" /> [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]] rejected this work and insisted on adding other volumes.<ref name=":1" /> In 1405, under [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]]’s command, the number of scholars rose to 2,169. Scholars were sent all over [[China]] to find books and expand the [[encyclopedia]].<ref name=":1" /> In addition, [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]] assigned his personal advisor, Dao Yan, a monk, and Liu Jichi, the deputy minister of punishment, as co-editors of the encyclopedia, supporting [[Yao Guangxiao]].<ref name=":3">Tsai, Shih-Shan Henry. Perpetual The Ming Emperor Yongle, University of Washington Press, 2011. ProQuest Ebook Central, <nowiki>https://ebookcentral-proquest-com.oca.ucsc.edu/lib/ucsc/detail.action?docID=3444272</nowiki>.</ref> The scholars spent four years compiling the ''[[leishu]]'' encyclopedia, under the leadership of general editor [[Yao Guangxiao]].<ref name="Wilkinson">{{cite book |last=Wilkinson |first=Endymion |authorlink=Endymion Wilkinson |title=Chinese History: A Manual |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ERnrQq0bsPYC&pg=PA604 |year=2000 |publisher=Harvard University Asia Center |isbn=978-0-674-00249-4 |pages=604–5}}</ref>
The scholars incorporated 8,000 texts from ancient times through the early [[Ming dynasty]]. Many subjects were covered, including [[agriculture]], [[art]], [[astronomy]], [[drama]], [[geology]], [[history]], [[literature]], [[medicine]], [[natural sciences]], [[religion]] and [[technology]], as well as descriptions of unusual natural events.<ref name=WDL1>{{cite web|title=Yongle Encyclopedia|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/3019/|publisher=World Digital Library|accessdate=24 January 2013}}</ref>
The encyclopedia was completed in 1408<ref name="eb"/> at the [[Guozijian]] in [[Nanjing]] (now [[Nanjing University]]). It comprised 22,937 manuscript rolls<ref name="eb">{{cite web|title=Yongle dadian (Chinese encyclopaedia)|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/654973/Yongle-dadian|work=Encyclopædia Britannica Online|accessdate=9 May 2012|author=Kathleen Kuiper|location=Chicago, Illinois|date=31 Aug 2006}} ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica|Encyclopædia Britannica Inc.]]''</ref> or chapters, in 11,095 volumes, occupying roughly 40 cubic meters (1400 ft<sup>3</sup>), and using 370 million [[Chinese characters]].<ref name=WDL1/><ref>{{cite web |author=陈红彦 |title= 国家图书馆《永乐大典》收藏史话 |date=2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226010714/http://www.nlc.gov.cn/old2008/service/wjls/pdf/04/04_04_a4b7c3.pdf |archivedate=December 26, 2016 |publisher=[[National Library of China]] |url=http://www.nlc.gov.cn/old2008/service/wjls/pdf/04/04_04_a4b7c3.pdf }}</ref> It was designed to include all that had been written on the [[Chinese classics|Confucian canon]], as well as all history, philosophy, arts and sciences. It was a massive collation of excerpts and works from the entirety of Chinese literature and knowledge. [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]] was so pleased with the finished encyclopedia, that he named it after his reign, and personally wrote a lengthy preface highlighting the importance of preserving the works.<ref name=":2" />
==Style== [[File:Yongle Encyclopedia.jpg|thumb|The Yongle Encyclopedia, in 2014, on display at [[National Library of China|The National Library of China.]]]] The encyclopedia’s physical appearance differed from any other Chinese encyclopedias of the time.<ref name=":4">Campbell, Ducan. "The Huntington Library’s Volume of the Yongle Encyclopaedia (Yongle Dadian 湛樂댕듕): A Bibliographical and Historical Note." ''East Asian History'', no. 42 (March 2018): 1. <nowiki>http://www.eastasianhistory.org/42/campbell</nowiki>.</ref> It was bigger in size, used special paper, and was bound in a “wrapped back” or ([[包背裝]] bao bei zhuang) style.<ref name=":5">Clunas, Craig, and Jessica Harrison-Hall. ''The BP Exhibition: Ming: 50 Years That Changed China''. The British Museum, 2014.</ref> The use of red ink for titles and authors, an ink exclusively reserved for the emperor, helped to confirm that the volumes were of royal production.<ref name=":4" /> Each volume was protected by a hard-cover which was wrapped in yellow [[silk]].<ref name=":5" /> The [[encyclopedia]] was not arranged by subject, like other encyclopedias, instead it was arranged by [[洪武正韻]] (Hongwu zhengyun) a system in which characters are ordered [[Phonetics|phonetically]]/rhythmically.<ref name=":5" /> The use of this system helped the reader find specific entries with ease.<ref name=":5" /> Although book printing already existed in the [[Ming dynasty|Ming Dynasty]], the Yongle Encyclopedia was exclusively handwritten.<ref name=":5" /> Each handwritten entry was a collection of existing literature, some of which derived from rare and delicate texts.<ref name=":5" /> The importance of the Yongle Encyclopedia was the preservation of such texts, and the vast number of subjects it covered.<ref name=":5" />
== Reception == At the end of the [[Ming dynasty]], scholars began to question [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]]’s motives for not commissioning more copies of the [[encyclopedia]], instead of keeping them in storage.<ref name=":2" /> Some scholars, like Sun Chengze, a Qin scholar, theorized that [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]] used the literary project for political reasons.<ref name=":2" /> At the time, [[Neo-Confucianism|Neo-Confucians]] were refusing to take civil service exams, or participate in any imperial duties, due to [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]]'s violent usurpation of the throne.<ref name=":2" /> [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]]’s literary undertaking did attract the attention of these scholars, who eventually joined the project.<ref name=":2" /> Because [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]] did not want a strictly [[Confucianism|Confucian]] point of view for the encyclopedia, Non-Confucian scholars were also included, and contributed to the [[Buddhism]], [[Taoism|Daoism]], and [[Divination]] sections of the encyclopedia.<ref name=":2" /> The inclusion of these subjects intensified the scrutiny against [[Yongle Emperor|Emperor Yongle]] amongst [[Neo-Confucianism|Neo-Confucians]] who believed the encyclopedia was nothing but “''wheat and chaff''".<ref name=":2" /> However, despite the varied opinions, the encyclopedia is widely regarded as a priceless contribution in preserving a wide range of China's historic works, many of which would be lost otherwise.
==Disappearance== The ''Yongle Dadian'' was not [[printing|printed]] for the general public, because the treasury had run out of funds when it was completed in 1408. It was placed in [[Wenyuan Ge]] (文渊阁) in Nanjin after completed until 1421 Yongle Empire moved the capital to Beijing, along with the Yongle Dadian, and placed it in the [[Forbidden City]] in Beijing.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lauren Christos|date=2010-01-04|title=The Yongle Dadian: The Origin, Destruction, Dispersal and Reclamation of a Chinese Cultural Treasure|url=http://140.122.104.2/ojs/index.php/jlis/article/view/538|journal=圖書館學與資訊科學|language=en|volume=36|issue=1|issn=2224-1574}}</ref> In 1557, during the reign of the [[Jiajing Emperor]], the encyclopedia was narrowly saved from a fire that burnt down three palaces in the [[Forbidden City]]. A manuscript copy was commissioned by Jiajing Emperor in 1562 and completed in 1567.<ref name=Wilkinson/> The original copy was lost afterwards. There are three major hypotheses for its disappearance, but no conclusion was made:
*Destroyed in late Ming Dynasty. [[Li Zicheng]], rebel leader, in 1644 overthrew the Ming Dynasty and took over the Ming capital, Beijing. A few months later, he was defeated by the coalition of [[Wu Sangui]] and [[Dorgon]]. Li burned the Forbidden City when he withdrew from Beijing.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://news.ifeng.com/a/20170311/50771110_0.shtml|title=《永乐大典》 正本陪葬了嘉靖帝？|last=Lin|first=Guang|date=2017-02-28|work=《北京日报》|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> The Yongle Dadian may have been destroyed in the fire. *Buried with Jiajing Emperor. The time when the Jiajing Emperor was buried was very close to the time of completion of the manuscript copy. Jiajing Emperor died in December 1566, but was buried three months later, in March 1567.<ref name=":6" /> One possibility is that they were waiting for the manuscript to be completed. *Burned in [[Palace of Heavenly Purity|Qianqing Palace]] fire.
The original manuscript of the ''Yongle Dadian'' was almost completely lost by the end of the Ming dynasty,<ref name=Wilkinson/> but 90 percent of the 1567 manuscript survived until the [[Second Opium War]] in the [[Qing dynasty]]. In 1860, the [[Battle of Palikao|Anglo-French invasion of Beijing]] resulted in extensive burning and looting of the city,<ref name=FootWoolf2012>{{cite book|last1=Foot|first1=Sarah|authorlink1=Sarah Foot|last2=Woolf|first2=Daniel R.|last3=Robinson|first3=Chase F.|title=The Oxford History of Historical Writing: Volume 2: 400-1400 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bzmBxU39PGMC&pg=PA42 |year=2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-923642-8|page=42}}</ref> with the British and French soldiers taking large portions of the manuscript as souvenirs.<ref name=Wilkinson/> 5,000 volumes remained by 1875, less than half of the original, which dwindled to 800 by 1894. During the [[Boxer Rebellion]] and the 1900 [[Eight-Nation Alliance]] [[Battle of Beijing (1900)|occupation of Beijing]], allied soldiers took hundreds of volumes, and many were destroyed in the [[Hanlin Academy]] fire. Only 60 volumes remained in Beijing.<ref name=Wilkinson/>
==Current status== Fewer than 400 volumes survive today,<ref name=WDL1/> comprising about 800 chapters (rolls), or 3.5 percent of the original work.<ref name=FootWoolf2012/> The most complete collection is kept at the [[National Library of China]] in Beijing, which holds 221 volumes.<ref name=WDL1/> The next largest collection is at the [[National Palace Museum]] in [[Taipei]], which holds 62 volumes.<ref>[http://www.npm.gov.tw/english/exhbition/ease0101/selec04.htm Yung-lo ta-tien (Vast Documents of the Yung-lo Era)] ''[[National Palace Museum]]''</ref>
51 volumes are in the United Kingdom held at the [[British Library]], the [[Bodleian Library]] in [[Oxford]], the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] of the [[University of London]], and [[Cambridge University Library]]; The [[Library of Congress]] of the United States holds 41 volumes; [[Cornell University Library]] has 6 volumes; and 5 volumes are held in various libraries in [[Germany]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://china.org.cn/english/PP-e/31248.htm |title=Experts Urge Collectors To Share World's Earliest Encyclopedia |work=Xinhua News Agency|date=April 2002 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Holdings of Yong Le Da Dian in United Kingdom Libraries |first=David |last=Helliwell |publisher=Bodleian Library|url=http://www.bodley.ox.ac.uk/users/djh/serica/oldchinesebooks/YongleEurope.pdf}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Chinese encyclopedias]] *''[[Four Great Books of Song]]'' *''[[Gujin Tushu Jicheng]]'' *''[[Siku Quanshu]]''
== References == === Citations === {{Reflist}}
=== Sources === {{refbegin}} * Ebrey, Patricia Buckley, Anne Walthall, James B. Palais. (2006). ''East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History''. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. {{ISBN|0-618-13384-4}}. * Guo Bogong (郭佰恭). ''Yongle dadian kao'' 永樂大典考. Shanghai: Commercial Press, 1937. {{refend}}
